items.title: £400 per household per year to achieve net zero? A bargain, surely? But…
items.summary: Phil Goodwin points to new data that exposes the ‘absurdities’ of treating the carbon impact of the road programme, and its individual schemes, as trivially insignificant.

items.title: A time for sharing?
items.summary: Planning how we cater for future personal transport needs, and in particular for the future of the private car.

items.title: Do we know where we’re going?
items.summary: History tells us that we very often just cannot see what is going to change our world, and our lives.

items.title: This might turn out to be another significant moment
items.summary: Arman Farahmand-Razavi offers his personal reflections on a forum that embraced the big issues of our time, and how it has reminded him of past gatherings of the sector’s leading thinkers.

items.title: An important new dimension in talking about tackling climate change
items.summary: Although this declaration is not legally binding, it opens up an important new dimension in the political and business sectors’ agenda in talking about tackling climate change.

items.title: If you’re in a hole… it must be time to rethink Stonehenge scheme
items.summary: Updated values would reveal the true cost of building a tunnel under Stonehenge, says Phil Goodwin. He urges National Highways to think again.

items.title: Pressures for change - to the context in which transport is considered - are only going to multiply
items.summary: We should expect more elements of the transport landscape to be fought over as either ‘right or wrong’ for the future of the planet.

items.title: The transport industry is not known for going too far beyond its boundaries for the top jobs
items.summary: Who else is out there in the potential talent pool for the challenging new roles that securing the nation’s best transport future in a changing world is regularly throwing up.

items.title: Whilst challenging the Government’s funding distribution model - the NIC has not been quite bold enough
items.summary: A transport taxation and distribution re-think is surely now also very much due, with the expected pending diminution of the established fuel tax revenue model.

items.title: Why we must recognise the true impact of climate change in transport appraisal
items.summary: ‘Baseline’ forecasts should be urgently revised so they reflect the current trajectory of global warming.

items.title: Reshaping and rethinking our role, and its delivery
items.summary: As we re-appear in a new format, after a summer break, the obvious need for a carefully curated and structured fortnightly take on UK transport has been clearer than ever.

items.title: We are now facing two alternative futures, plus an untenable one
items.summary: Phil Goodwin and Jillian Anable discuss the role of transport decarbonisation in addressing the impacts of climate change.

items.title: Time to get back to normal and kick-start business as usual?
items.summary: The line on a graph called ‘business as usual’ has simply become meaningless. Yes, we plead, let us feel we can lead normal lives, but for planning and forecasting we cannot credibly translate that into a tenable description of normality.

items.title: Transport appraisal and planning in a time of imperatives
items.summary: All discussion of strategic and local transport planning at present is seen through the lens of the urgent imperatives of the pandemic, which have changed the boundaries of policy in contradictory directions.

items.title: Driving change: travel in the 21st century
items.summary: Some of the worst mistakes in transport investment have been supported by huge volumes of forecasts, surveys and studies, confidently published with little recognition of their inconsistencies and errors.
